https://prez.dev/description.@value: The stage of a borehole in relation to the lifecycle of the borehole, from proposal and operational stages through to completion and rehabilitation, and with a focus on terminology as applied in the Geological Survey of Western Australia (GSWA) databases. The vocabulary focuses on standard terminology from the energy and mineral resources sectors, highlighting instances where the same term carries different meaning in different fields. In the context of this vocabulary, the term fluid energy refers to sources such as gas, petroleum and geothermal, as covered by the Petroleum Legislation Amendment Act 2024, and is exclusive of mineral sources of energy (e.g. coal, uranium). Note that the currency of borehole status data in GSWA's databases is time-stamped, reflecting information gathered from a borehole operatorâ€™s well completion report or from a responsible regulatory authority at a specific point in time; subsequent changes are unlikely to be recorded.

Drilling of a borehole has been approved by the relevant authorities, whether within a resource company, a government regulatory agency (e.g. as part of government-supported exploration drilling initiatives or for research purposes), indigenous representative groups, a research organisation, or as part of geotechnical investigations and/or infrastructure programs. Drilling has not yet commenced.
A borehole that was proposed in concept and/or approved on application, but was never drilled. This does not include the circumstance where the status is 'unknown'.
Refers to the stated intention of drilling a borehole that has yet to be submitted for approval from the relevant authorities.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Planning and approval include all stages from the initial conception of a borehole through to obtaining necessary approval(s) from the relevant authorities, whether within a resource company, a government regulatory agency, indigenous representative groups, a research organisation, or as part of geotechnical investigations and/or infrastructure programs.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: Planning and approval include all stages from the initial conception of a borehole through to obtaining necessary approval(s) from the relevant authorities, whether within a resource company, a government regulatory agency, indigenous representative groups, a research organisation, or as part of geotechnical investigations and/or infrastructure programs.
An application exists to drill a borehole, but drilling has not yet commenced or been approved.
